document.title: New VLBI Constraints for 0957+561 Lens Models

creator.contact: Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, Cambridge, MA 02138
Institute for Advanced Study, Princeton, NJ 08540

abstract.name: Abstract
abstract.p:
Time-delay measurements of 0957+561 based on radio monitoring (Haarsma et al. 1999) now agree with optical monitoring (Oscoz et al. 1997; Kundic et al. 1997). Recent models (Barkana et al. 1999; Bernstein & Fischer 1999) incorporate many recent observations, but the systematic uncertainties in the models still dominate the uncertainty in the cosmological results. VLBI observations of the milli-arcsec jet structure have provided the most important set of modeling constraints. We present new observations of this structure, made at 18 cm with the Very Long Baseline Array, the Very Large Array, and the Green Bank 140 ft. telescope. Compared to the data set of Garrett et al. (1994), ours has a similar theoretical noise level (20
μ
Jy), but nearly twice as many baselines (66 compared to 36) and more uniform coverage of the UV plane. Our initial maps confirm the basic jet structures seen by Garrett et al., with comparable RMS noise (60-80
μ
Jy), and are in reasonable agreement with the jet structure model of Barkana et al. (1999). The maps also hint at a new compact component leaving the core, and a previously undetected diffuse component at the end of the jet. Further refinements in fringe-fitting, mapping, and self-calibration should yield significantly lower RMS noise (closer to the theoretical level). We will use a modified form of the CalTech VLBI Modelfit program (written by Barkana et al. 1999) to determine the magnification matrix between the images. The refined magnification matrix should provide stronger constraints on the lens model, and thus reduce the uncertainty in the cosmological results.

document.keywords: gravitational lensing, cosmology: observations, distance scale, radio continuum: galaxies, quasars: individual (0957+561A,B)

figure.toccaption: 2Maps of 0957+561 A and B at 18 cm. The contours are plotted at intervals of -0.15, 0.15, 0.3, 0.6, 1.2, 2.4, 4.8, 9.6 mJy/beam. The 4 mas restoring beam is shown in the lower left.
figure.caption: Figure 2Maps of 0957+561 A and B at 18 cm. The contours are plotted at intervals of -0.15, 0.15, 0.3, 0.6, 1.2, 2.4, 4.8, 9.6 mJy/beam. The 4 mas restoring beam is shown in the lower left.

p.text: Barkana, R., Lehár, J., Falco, E. E., Grogin, N. A., Keeton, C. R., and Shapiro, I. I. 1999, ApJ, 520, 479
Bernstein, G. and Fischer, P. 1999, AJ, 118, 14
Haarsma, D. B., Hewitt, J. N., Lehár, J., and Burke, B. F. 1999, ApJ, 510, 64
Oscoz, A., Mediavilla, E., Goicoechea, L. J., Serra-Ricart, M., and Buitrago, J. 1997, ApJ, 479, L89
This page contains additional material from the poster which did not fit in the published proceedings.
Simulation: The Potential of Lensed Time Delays for Cosmology

para.p:
The fundamental cosmological result from lensed time delays is not
H 0
, but the angular diameter distance to the lens (Narayan 1991).

If we could measure the angular diameter distance to several lenses, then we could set limits on the matter density of the universe
Ω m
and the cosmological constant
Ω λ
.

Simulation details: Assuming
=
Ω m
0.3
,
=
Ω λ
0.7
, use the redshift for each lens to calculate its angular diameter distance. Add 15% Gaussian errors to each lens distance. Then use distances to fit for
Ω m
and
Ω λ
. The figure shows the resulting 68% confidence intervals.

As of early July 1999, there were 15 lenses with point images and known lens and source redshifts. If a time delay could be measured for each of these, we could have comparable results to 42 Type Ia Supernovae (Perlmutter et al. 1999).
